content.description:
The coral species Acropora millepora is a marine animal that has a symbiotic relationship with algae species in the genus Symbiodinium. An increase in the concentration of dissolved <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in oceans has a negative impact on this relationship and the health of the coral species. Scientists investigated the effect of <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> concentrations on the number of algae cells found in the coral (Figure 1) and on both the gross (total) and net rates of photosynthesis of those algae (Figure 2). The net rate of photosynthesis is equal to the gross rate of photosynthesis minus the rate of respiration by the algae.

Figure 1. Effect of <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> concentration on the number of algae per <math alttext="square centimeters" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> of coral. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus 2 S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mtext>SE</mtext><mover accent="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover></msub></math>.

Figure 2. Average gross and net rates of photosynthesis in algae under various concentrations of <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus 2 S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mtext>SE</mtext><mover accent="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover></msub></math>.
content.question:
Researchers observe that the water with the high <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> concentration has a lower <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>pH</mi></math> than does the water with the low <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> concentration. The researchers claim that lower <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> alters the structure of the enzymes of photosynthesis.

Which of the following most likely explains how a lower <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> could alter the structure of photosynthetic enzymes?

choices.label: There will not be enough <math alttext="H with a positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions for the ribosome to correctly form peptide bonds between amino acids during synthesis of the enzymes.

There will not be enough <math alttext="H with a positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions for the necessary hydrogen bonds to form in the secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures of the enzymes.

There will be additional <math alttext="H with a positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions that can disrupt peptide bonds in the primary structure of the enzymes.

There will be additional <math alttext="H with a positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions that can disrupt hydrogen bonds in the secondary, tertiary and quaternary structures of the enzymes.

content.answer: There will be additional <math alttext="H with a positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions that can disrupt hydrogen bonds in the secondary, tertiary and quaternary structures of the enzymes.
